ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to oil paint, work with color, and refine my brushstrokes.
I learned about how to create and use value, depth, contrast, color, and perspective in painting. I also learned how to use oil paint, charcoal, jesso, and various other painting materials.
Knowledge of depth, color, saturation, and how these components make up a painting. We learned how to oil paint, do plein-air painting, and enjoy the process of creating art.

Learned painting techniques involving background, foreground, middleground, creating depth through contrast, composition that the eyes could easily follow (and other various composition techniques), learned blocking out in inverse colors, complementary colors, texture, looking & studying from life, et cetera.
The course was an introduction to oil painting. We learned about composition and color theory. We spent most of the class time painting.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I enjoyed the freedom of this course, however, I do wish that there was a bit more instruction with regards to technique.

It was fun, fast-paced, and interesting. I particularly liked how much freedom we had to experiment and paint what we wanted to paint. One weakness was that I think I could have used a little more practice and help with creating perspective and with just simple painting techniques like brush strokes, etc. I didn't really know how to paint, and we sort of got thrown into the deep end and were asked to paint a bunch before learning how.

I think this course is a great introduction to painting. It was a bit tough over Zoom, but Professor Hysen accommodated everyone as much as possible. I felt that a large strength of the course was Professor Hysen's knowledge and feedback, which greatly helped everyone improve their paintings in the latter half of the class.
I love the professor and her ability to find the style and encourage the works and strengths of anyone who takes the course. It was honestly great.
Professor Hysen was super nice. I liked that the course wasn't very stressful. I was able to get useful feedback on my work. A clearer, more detailed syllabus could improve the course.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would recommend this course to someone interested in learning the basics of oil painting.
Yes! Painting Basics is fun, flexible, and relaxing. No pressure and you learn some stuff and have a good time.

I would absolutely recommend that you take painting, especially if it's in person the next time it's offered. I felt that I grew tremendously as an artist and learned a lot from Professor Hysen and my peers. The assignments don't feel like homework, and it's a really fun class. My major isn't adjacent to art in any way, but I still recommend that you take an art class at Yale at some point -- Painting Basics is a great place to start.
Yes, we learn real techniques and planar painting (from life) using a French easel provided me with a new and exciting outdoor hobby.
Yes! Prof Hysen is really nice and the course isn't hard. It is quite a bit of work (painting), which I didn't mind, but that's something to be aware of.
